title: Chair (Kiti Cha Enzi)

thumbnail.alt_text: Wooden chair with woven cotton seat, back, footrest.

artist_display:
Swahili
Lamu, Kenya
Eastern and Southern Africa
description: This style of high-backed seat with bone and ivory inlay, known as a “chair of power” or “grandee’s chair” (kiti cha enzi), is a graphic reminder of the complex history of international trade and conquest in the region known as the Swahili Coast. As early as the first century, the region’s natural harbors invited exchange with partners in the Persian Gulf and Western India. Later the Portuguese, Omani, and British imposed their authority on its inhabitants. With each conquering state, newly imported goods and practices took root as symbols of authority and power among the Swahili elite. The upright form of the kiti cha enzichair bears strong resemblance to sixteenth- and seventeenth-century chairs imported from Portugal and Spain, as well as to Portuguese- and Spanish-influenced examples made in India. Comparisons have also been made with chairs from the Mamluk period (1250–1517) in Egypt. In any case, the Swahili version is clearly the result of foreign influences that have been artfully synthesized and reshaped by local artisans. Most such chairs in collections today date from the nineteenth century and were made in large, specialized workshops. They could be found conspicuously displayed in wealthy households along the Swahili Coast into the first half of the twentieth century.
credit_line: Purchased with funds provided by Marshall Field V
publication_history:
James de Vere Allen, “The Kiti Cha Enzi and other Swahili Chairs,” African Arts, vol. 22, no. 3 (May 1989), pp. 54–63, 88; 55 (ill.).

Kathleen Bickford Berzock, “Chair (Kiti Cha Enzi),” Notable Acquisitions at the Art Institute, Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies 32, 1 (2006), pp. 10-11, 94.

Kathleen Bickford Berzock, "Chair (Kiti Cah Enzi)," The Silk Road and Beyond: Travel, Trade, and Transformation, Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies, 33, 1 (2007), pp. 55-56.

Gary van Wyk. 2013. "Art Practice in Tanzania: Landscape, Soundscape, Engurance." In
Shangaa: Art of Tanzania, exh. cat., Gary van Wyk, ed., (Queens Community College Art Gallery Press, 2013), pg. 72, fig. 1.25 (ill.).
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, The Silk Road and Beyond: Travel, Trade, and Transformation, Sept. 30, 2006–Apr. 22, 2007, cat. pp. 55-56 (ill).
provenance_text: Studio Sanaa, Mombasa, Kenya, by about 1979; sold to unnamed owner, Los Angeles, Calif., about 1979; sold to Davis Gallery, New Orleans, La., 1989; sold to the Art Institute, 2004.
